Act1Scene3Part3a.speaker: Ross
Act1Scene3Part3a.text: The King hath happily received, Macbeth, The news of thy success

Act1Scene3Part3a.speaker: Angus
Act1Scene3Part3a.text: We are sent To give thee from our royal master thanks, only to herald thee into his sight, not pay thee
Act1Scene3Part3a.translation: We are sent to give you thanks from our royal master King Duncan, only to bring you to him, not to pay you.

Act1Scene3Part3a.speaker: Ross
Act1Scene3Part3a.text:
And for an earnest of a greater honor, he bade me, from him,
call thee Thane of Cawdor, in which addition, hail, most worthy thane, for it is thine.
Act1Scene3Part3a.translation: And as a down payment on an even greater honor, he told me to call you Thane of Cawdor. So hail, most worthy thane, because it's yours now.

Act1Scene3Part3a.speaker: Banquo
Act1Scene3Part3a.text: What, can the devil speak true?

Act1Scene3Part3a.speaker: Macbeth
Act1Scene3Part3a.text: The Thane of Cawdor lives. Why do you dress me In borrowed robes?
Act1Scene3Part3a.translation: The Thane of Cawdor is still alive. Why are you addressing me as if I where him?

Act1Scene3Part3a.speaker: Angus
Act1Scene3Part3a.text: Who was the Thane lives yet, But under heavy judgment bears that life which he deserves to lose

Act1Scene3Part3a.speaker: Angus
Act1Scene3Part3a.translation: He worked against his country, I don't know how. But he confessed to and was found guilty of high treason, and that's why he was overthrown.
